ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live and recorded virtual lecture
I attended some live sessions
Lectures are recorded.
Virtual Office Hours (super helpful!!)
lectures were recorded
Lecture also recorded
live lecture
We had live online lectures during class. The lectures were recorded and could be watched at anytime.
study sections
Live Virtual Lecture

We had live lectures on Zoom twice a week.  The professor shared his screen to show his slides, and he annotated the slides using his iPad.  The professor and ULAs were also active on Piazza, and posted slides and other helpful files on Canvas.  Finally, assignment turn-in, grading, and feedback was done through Gradescope.
Live virtual lecture and recorded lecture

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: DEEP understanding about the theorems in probability. You'll really think in this class.
probability
I learned the basics about statistical probability.
General knowledge of probability theory.
Everything in the course syllabus that I expected to learn
Probability Theory - ALSO SUPER helpful for ECON majors (specifically, for ECON 117)!

basic probability introduction 
intro to distributions, random variables, etc.
Basic knowledge of probability theory
Learned the basics of probability theory. Counting all the way to different distributions
I have come to understand the basics of probability theory and feel prepared to continue taking more S&DS courses.
I learned basic probability theory rules and concepts, which drew upon basic Calculus skills
probability, counting, distributions, expected value, MGFs, Joint distributions, covariance snd correlation, convolutions, inequalities
Useful tools for statistical analysis
I developed strong analytical skills from this course. It helped me a lot in understanding many of the fundamentals of probability theory and statistics.
basic probability theory

Through this course, students get an in-depth exploration of determining probabilities as they relate to random variables.  In so doing, we learn about several discrete and continuous distributions (e.g., Binomial, Poisson, Normal) that are crucial to future studies and statistical analyses that students will likely undertake.
I gained a basic knowledge of probability

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Harry Zhou is a gem ... the bridge between concept and application could be improved but the professor did spend a lot of time and energy to help with this.

Good lectures, harry is a good explainer. I think there is a decent amount of material that isn't covered in the lectures though which is a bit annoying since not all the material in the textbook is relevant either.
The TA's are fantastic, but I just generally dislike classes where there's such a strong culture of going to office hours to get a ton of help and/or answers for the pset. Don't think there's an easy solution, but just something that bothers me because this feels like an issue at some point in the learning process

Strength: I feel like this kinda stuff is useful so I was glad to learn it
Weakness: I wasn't used to writing up proofs for things(even though the proofs we did were basic) or doing at math from such an abstract standpoint at times so it was hard to keep up a lot of the times

Strengths: kind professor who cares about students' learning. course was structured well-- very clear how each topic built upon the last.

Weaknesses: 9am online MW is just not the play.
Great course! The professor clearly knows how to design a good course.

Strengths: offered enough office hours, professor was readily available to help with material
Weaknesses: lectures were confusing and did not go over enough nuance to prepare students for problem sets or exams
Really great course

Professor Zhou is just amazing. The only thing is that most of the answers to the problem sets can be found online, so I found my friends not actually engaging with the material. 

Office Hours are vital for this class, everyone should be attending office hours. ALSO, attend class live if possible, it's way better.

good recorded lectures
sometimes hard to understand how to broadly apply lessons to multiple problems (some might be intuition based)
Interesting material and good lecture but hard to absorb everything at such a fast pace
Could have had more office hours for students in different time zones

The course is organized in a way that allows understanding of lecture material to be evaluated through problem sets. Through this way of learning, it is really easy to come to learn what you truly understand and what you need help with. Plus, with amazing peer tutors, it is very easy to get help beyond the professor's office hours.

Lectures are very well taught and clear, and the TAs and professor are always kind and willing to help. A lot of support is offered during office hours, which I greatly appreciate. I loved learning under Harryhe is an incredibly caring professor.

I found exams to be very challenging, and I think this stemmed from not having enough practice problems. The practice midterms and finals were quite helpful, but I wish we could have been given more optional practice problems to work on (the practice problems in the textbook were very challenging).
Prof Harry is nice but not very good at teaching--a lot of the work will have to be learnt on your own time while doing psets, textbook readings e.t.c
If you can take this class with Harry then totally worthwhile. The class sped up at the end which was hard to keep up with

Professor Zhou is a great teacher and was a main strength of the course. He is very helpful and wants to make sure his students learn as much as possible. He is very helpful during office hours as well. For improvement, aside from the psets, there could potentially be additional assignments to practice the material.
course covers interesting material at a very digestible pace.

The only strength was the professor's lenient grading. He introduced multiple different grading options to favor students throughout the semester. The main weakness of this course was that the recorded lectures were extremely difficult to understand due to the professor's heavy accent.

This course is extremely effective in making students, who may not be from a statistics/math background, move rapidly from a superficial to thorough understanding of probability.  The strengths lie in the excellent organization of the course, in addition to Professor Zhou's wonderful lectures and attitude.  The slides provide a condensed version of the textbook for efficient review of material.  The problem sets address key concepts without necessitating extra experience with mathematical reasoning beyond the prerequisites and what is taught in lecture.  Professor Zhou's lectures are engaging and instrumental to the success of the course.  
A large portion of the grade was left to the two exams, and I may have expected the weekly assignments to comprise a larger portion of the grade. However, I understand that this is how it's done in many S&DS and math courses at Yale, and the exams were definitely reasonable.
The course was excellent except that it required much more of a knowledge of calculus than I was prepared for. So students should be warned of that.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I mean the recorded lectures were key because there was no way I was getting up for every single 6am lecture. I would say that the weekly psets were nice to make sure I was keeping up with the material, but they were quite a bit of work. It might have been nice to have a more centralized calendar/link list of office hours
Office hours were very helpful, as well as facilitating students asking questions throughout lectures.
Lecture was recorded which helped a lot. Would've liked if the lecture slides were adjusted on Canvas based on which material we skipped over.
It was geared well, but I felt that the final was really tough to prevent cheating. It was also hard to do group work with other students on psets cause of remote learning
There was constant communication between students and the professor at all times. He was so accommodating and really wanted to create an environment that would truly foster learning.
This course was well adjusted to virtual learning. In class and in office hours, TAs and Harry would share their tablet screens to write out work, which was very helpful
Pace of the class
The office hours hosted by Professor Zhou and the TFs allowed for virtual engagement with them and with other students as well.
all succeeded very well, including compared to how it would be without covid.

We had live lectures on Zoom twice a week, in which students interacted with the professor by unmuting themselves or typing in the chat.  The professor shared his screen to show his slides, and he annotated the slides using his iPad.  The professor and ULAs were also active on Piazza, and posted slides and other helpful files on Canvas.  Finally, assignment turn-in, grading, and feedback was done through Gradescope.  All methods worked very well, the course experience was smooth, and learning was effective.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it's very well taught with a professor who really cares about your improvement and growth
Yes, it's well taught and you definitely learn the concepts. Very good prof and TAs
yes but only if you have a strong interest in statistics or need this course for other ones.

Take it if you need to. It's not bad at all--prof was great and the level of difficulty was appropriate--but it hasn't been my most interesting class here and I wouldn't have taken it if I didn't need to
Yes, if you want to gain general knowledge about probability theory.
Yup. Great intro class

Absolutely. I love Professor Zhou, he cares so much and is an amazing professor. He is an absolute genius in the field but still makes the material understandable. He was extremely accommodating during the pandemic. Overall 10/10 please take this course.
yes if you need it for the certificate
Yes, but only if you are willing to actually learn the material. Pretty demanding for an introductory course.
yeah.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student who is interested in S&DS. I am a non-S&DS major and found the course to be really applicable to other courses I am taking. If you put in the effort, you should be able to do well. 

Also, the biggest reason you should take this course is Professor Zhou !!! He is one of the best professors I have ever had and truly cares about his students. I loved going to class and his office hours, even if it was just to casually chat. He is the best !!

I would recommend this course to another student! Familiarity with calculus will be helpful. The exams are quite challenging and worth a large portion of your grade, so make sure to prepare well for those
Not if Harry is teaching it. Yes otherwise.
If with Harry then yes!
I would recommend this course to another student interested in learning probability theory in an environment where the professor tries to make sure students learn as much as possible.
if interested in a slow exploration of basic data analysis

I would not recommend this course. If you're considering taking this course, it's probably because you want to learn probability theory while taking a course that is supposed to be slightly easier than S&DS 241. This course is not much easier than S&DS 241; in fact, all of our practice midterms were those from 241. So if you're taking this course and expecting something easier, you will be thoroughly disappointed. While it certainly is possible to get an A, you will have to work hard and score highly on tests to do so. With all this said, Harry is lenient on grading, as he introduced multiple different grading options throughout the semester to support students. The professor is nice, but unless you listen carefully, it is difficult to understand him at times because of his accent.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student, primarily for two reasons.  First, the course is very well-organized and facilitates effective student learning.  Second, the goal of having this S&DS 240 course, in addition to 241, is definitely achieved - as a senior whose most recent experience in math was in high school, I was able to follow all stages of the course and perform well.

I would recommend this course to a student who really is interested in the topic or who absolutely needs it. It's a challenging course and requires a lot of thought and time to do the problem sets and the exams were hard but the professor was kind and a very good teacher.

extras.title:
S&DS 540 01/S&DS 240 01
        Probability Theory/Intro to Probability Theory
